unnormalised: Automotive Alert: Delhi Traffic Gets a Festival Facelift!
normalised: Automotive Alert: Delhi Traffic Gets a Festival Facelift!

unnormalised: Listen up, Delhiites! With Onam just around the corner and traffic already feeling like a plate of unfinished biryani – a complete mess! – Delhi Traffic Police are cracking down on violations. Expect increased patrolling, especially around market areas like Chandni Chowk, where finding parking is already a Herculean task.
normalised: Listen up, Delhiites! With Onam just around the corner and traffic already feeling like a plate of unfinished biryani – a complete mess! – Delhi Traffic Police are cracking down on violations. Expect increased patrolling, especially around market areas like Chandni Chowk, where finding parking is already a Herculean task.

unnormalised: New rules are being implemented near ISBT Anand Vihar, specifically targeting overloaded autos and haphazardly parked buses. Fines are hefty, starting at Rs. 500 for minor offenses and escalating to Rs. 5,000 for repeat offenders.
normalised: New rules are being implemented near I S B T Anand Vihar, specifically targeting overloaded autos and haphazardly parked buses. Fines are hefty, starting at rupees five hundred for minor offenses and escalating to rupees five thousand for repeat offenders.

unnormalised: The crackdown aims to improve traffic flow by at least 20% during the festival season, according to a statement released by the Joint Commissioner of Police (Traffic), Mr. Sharma. They're also implementing a one-way system on select roads and installing new CCTV cameras to monitor hotspots. So, buckle up, drive safe, and remember to follow the rules, folks. Nobody wants a traffic ticket ruining their Onam celebrations! Plus, save that hard-earned cash for those delicious Onam Sadhya ingredients! Avoid over-speeding - 60 km/hr limit is enforced strictly on most roads.
normalised: The crackdown aims to improve traffic flow by at least twenty percent during the festival season, according to a statement released by the Joint Commissioner of Police (Traffic), Mister Sharma. They're also implementing a one-way system on select roads and installing new C C T V cameras to monitor hotspots. So, buckle up, drive safe, and remember to follow the rules, folks. Nobody wants a traffic ticket ruining their Onam celebrations! Plus, save that hard-earned cash for those delicious Onam Sadhya ingredients! Avoid over-speeding - sixty kilometer per hour limit is enforced strictly on most roads.
